job_title: Community Service Officer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: - A lot of the shifts are desk shifts, and though its not advisable, you can do some work while serving as watch. - Pay is reasonable, always slightly more than minimum wage, and you get promotions at a decent pace (i.e. you can keep the job through all 4 years and get paid more each year, if you push for the promotions). - Hours are reasonable and you can choose to work a lot or a little. - Co-workers and leadership are usually pretty great to work with and more reliable than your average college job.
cons: - A lot of shifts can be super boring and last up to 8 hours in a completely empty building. - You are mandated to do all the football games, unless you have a really good excuse to not attend. It could be very cold, rainy, windy, etc... and its really all the same. These shifts can be a little tough to get through. - Only "useful" for post-college if you plan to go into the public sector, as it gives a bit of rapport. Especially those interested in policing, but that timeline can be much longer.

pros: Rutgers provides great benefits. Great PTO and pension plan. The staff includes some of the most amazing people, who are passionate about helping the community.
cons: EISS does not practice what it preaches. Unsafe staffing, unethical practices are encouraged to keep the numbers up and disregard for policies is what the Newark office continues to promote. For a mental health program, upper management continues to jeopardize the mental health of its staff and disregard the needs of the consumers by stacking sessions. Consumers do not get the care they require and deserve. This is reflected in the high turnover rate and decreased morale. Working before hours and after hours is common within the team as a way to try to stay afloat as management continues to unsafely schedule consumers. I would not recommend this program to anyone.

The university president talks about Diversity, Inclusion and Equity but that doesn't seem to extend to everyone since there is NO SALARY EQUITY. The salaries are public. The president and his cabinet make 1M and 700K or over but managers with many years of service, who are forced to work 60-70 hours/week, are making $90K and looking at a maximum 2% raise/year. 
 Compensation is very poor relative to the amount of work that is required. Not good for career because there is no exposure to the most current software. There is also very limited advancement opportunities but when they do happen, the university has it set up that the maximum salary increase you can receive is 15%. Health benefits, which used to be affordable, are now very expensive and are no longer an enticement to work there.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: It depends on where exactly you work, some departments are quite relaxed.
cons: As a post-doctoral fellow, the policy is to not update your salary schedule ever. This means that you may be working for 5 years at Rutgers and earn less than a person who was just hired with no experience. Only 12 days of PTO. As a post-doc, you have no choice of health insurance (UHC StudentResources only, which is not great) and no possibility of vision insurance. Maximum 14 days of sick leave per year. No housing is available for post-docs, only for students, Ph.D. students, or more senior staff. No daycare is available for post-docs (except if you have more than 1 child). No retirement plan, no FSA/HSA. You have to pay to park where you work (0.5% of your salary).

review_title: Great students and staff, poor management
job_title: Senior Administrator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Students and support staff are amazing for the most part. Benefits are good - sick days, family leave, retirement match, tuition remission for family (all hard fought victories thanks to our unions, make no mistake!)
cons: From an actual staff person, not a student worker or TA: The reorganization of SAS is a joke. Find me a business school professor who thinks adding layers upon layers of middle management is a good idea... total waste of money and everyone’s time. Let the people in the trenches do our jobs and stop looking over our shoulders like we’re kids. Also the new finance system implementation has been a complete sh$&show and increased everyone’s workload substantially. Lots of people who’ve worked for the university for many years are taking early retirement because of the new (micro)management system and the ridiculous finance system. They are now suggesting that we take an “Accounting 101” training to be able to understand their convoluted system. We are not accountants nor are we paid enough to be, we are supposed to be supporting the professors and students but we’re so busy doing finance stuff that we have little time for helping the actual work of scholarly research and educating students happen. Poor leadership at the highest levels has allowed this to happen (Barchi, I’m looking at you). And the lack of respect shown at the bargaining table this year makes it painfully obvious that management gives less than two sh$&s about us. We do have great benefits, but they’re trying their hardest to take them away at every turn. Maybe spend less on football and invest in the people who actually make this university run!

job_title: Office of Information Technology Livingston Consultant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: This job has very flexible hours. You can also do your homework on the job or study if nothing else is going on the lab.  The job is typically very easy if you come from a technical background (ie. you're comfortable with technology and know what terms like IP address and task manager are), so it is low stress as well. You can also be excused from shifts with decent reasons (doctors appt, class, exam ,etc.) . Finally, you are also well-compensated for your work, with starting pay at $10.25 an hour. Overall, a perfect part-time job for a college student.
cons: The manager is over-bearing and condescending. You will not see him much. However, if you spend any amount of time with him you will quickly see that he is an arrogant and aggressive overbearer who will not hesitate to call rank when he has no good reason for what he's asking you to do. Do yourself a favor and stay off his radar, and nothing will keep you from enjoying this job. The supervisors on the other hand are very cool. They are Rutgers students just like you, so they are usually much more understanding and casual with management.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Health Insurance is pretty good with state health benefits.
cons: This con is, particularly for Mechanical Engineering. If you are a TA or grader in MAE department, I feel sorry for you. The underfunded department abuses the TA/graders to the fullest extent possible. While the mandated contract is for 15 hours per week, TAs are forced to work for +30 hours more often than not. While this may work for MS students, the cost-benefit analysis for PhDs is entirely unjustified. PhDs are supposed to do research. Even with a 75 hour work week, the time left to do research after considering coursework and TAs is a meager 35 hours. Good luck with finishing your degree with a 35 hour work week. What is especially sad is the sheer indifference that professors show towards this abuse. If the graders and TAs decided to come together and complain to the Dean or higher, pretty sure MAE will be in big trouble. Alas! most graduate students are internationals, with no knowledge about the redressal system and indeed scared of being suspended by the school and sent back. Which is why you probably won't hear this a lot.

review_title: Overall still a good place to work
job_title: in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The employees are dedicated and work diligently.  The benefits package, the tuition reimbursement for employee's children (they do have to qualify for admission, just like every other student), and the opportunity to advance one's own education.  The whole atmosphere of being on a research university campus is intellectually stimulating.  There is easy access to a huge variety of events on any number of topics.  And there is the connection to almost 250 years of history since it was founded before the Revolutionary War.  And of course the students.  Few workplaces have so many opportunities for intergenerational interaction, and every year's graduation gives a sense of accomplishment.
cons: The university is a public university, although the state provides a smaller and smaller percentage of the overall budget.  The budget cuts have forced so many layoffs, it is depressing.  And there have been no salary increases for years!  It is also stressful to work wondering if tomorrow there will be more and your own job could be the next one cut.  The deep cuts in administrative staff, force those who are left to assume more and more work, often on one's own time.  The pressure can be quite overwhelming.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Tuition Remission? Great health benefits. Wouldn't know. Don't have time to take advantage.
cons: My work life balance is gone. I got fat because I don't even have time to get up and walk around a little because I'm so busy. I'm miserable. I'm doing the work for 2 people. No one wants to train you. Literally no one. And if someone wants to train you, they know nothing about your current role. People here are dogmatic about knowledge hording. You'd think team work and communication are languages of extraterrestrial life forms. Every department/division has a specific role. It probably has something to do with another department/division. They don't know how it relates, and they genuinely don't care. You will see your work falling through the cracks as you desperately attempt to learn your role single-handedly and take on new tasks that are dumped on you. I hope you have a lot of ice cream, because you'll be crying into quite a few pints (consider eating with copious amounts of wine).
